unnormalised: Someone asked me, "How do retailers decide on prices?" It's a really interesting question! Let me break it down in an Indian context.
normalised: Someone asked me, "How do retailers decide on prices?" It's a really interesting question! Let me break it down in an Indian context.

unnormalised: A lot goes into setting prices. Let's say a shopkeeper in Sadar Bazaar buys a saree for Rs. 800. He won't just sell it for that! He needs to consider his costs like rent (maybe ₹10,000 per month), electricity bills, and staff salaries. Plus, he wants to make a profit! He might also factor in competitor pricing; if a similar saree is selling for Rs 1200 at a nearby shop, he might price his at Rs 1150 to attract customers. Seasonal sales also play a big role. During Diwali, he might offer a 10% discount on all sarees.
normalised: A lot goes into setting prices. Let's say a shopkeeper in Sadar Bazaar buys a saree for rupee eight hundred. He won't just sell it for that! He needs to consider his costs like rent (maybe rupee ten thousand per month), electricity bills, and staff salaries. Plus, he wants to make a profit! He might also factor in competitor pricing; if a similar saree is selling for rupee one thousand two hundred at a nearby shop, he might price his at rupee one thousand one hundred and fifty to attract customers. Seasonal sales also play a big role. During Diwali, he might offer a ten percent discount on all sarees.

unnormalised: Ultimately, the retailer is trying to find a balance between covering costs, attracting customers, and making a decent profit margin. That saree, originally costing Rs 800, might end up selling for anywhere between Rs. 1000 and Rs. 1300, depending on all these factors. And don't forget bargaining! A customer might haggle and bring the price down by ₹50 or even ₹100. It's all part of the shopping experience here!
